hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Based on a close examination of the [campaign button](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/466), [campaign ribbon](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/467), and [Watson photograph](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/468), explain how the Populist party appealed to voters.
2. What were some personal characteristics of Populists like Jim Weaver (as explained in the [biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/470))? How did those characteristics cater to the Populists voters?
3. In the [NC Congress speech](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/471), Isaac Smith, an African American Republican congressman, responded to C.H. Johnson, a white Populist congressman, by criticizing the Populist party for exploiting black voters. Why would the Populist party attract black voters? 
4. In the last paragraph of the [broadside](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/473), the writer encourages farmers to mobilize for action. What are his main arguments and how do they reflect the Populist party? Provide a contemporary example of the “little man” against the “giant corporation.”

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text:
1. Ask students to create a Populist song in the mold of the anti-saloon song from the [songbook](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/472), taking into account all of the arguments of the Populist party from the sources in this set.
2. Ask students to compare and contrast the Populist party and the contemporary Tea Party or Green Party, writing a two-to-three-page argumentative essay explaining how and why there are similarities and differences between the parties.

hasPart.name: Teaching Guide: Exploring the Populist Movement
Resources
hasPart.text:
1. [The Populist Party](http://projects.vassar.edu/1896/populists.html), Vassar College. 
2. [The Populist Movement and the Struggle for Reform](http://www.colorado.edu/AmStudies/lewis/2010/populism.htm), University of Colorado Boulder. 
3. [Jim Crow Stories: The Populist Movement](http://www.pbs.org/wnet/jimcrow/stories_org_populist.html), PBS.

hasPart.name: Overview
hasPart.text: In late-nineteenth-century United States, agrarian reformers in southern and midwestern states collaboratively organized for government action against business monopolies, exorbitant railroad rates, secret ballots and political corruption, and the gold standard for currency. Because the Republican and Democratic parties were not meeting their needs, these “common men” farmers and small business owners joined the “people’s party” or Populist party as a third- party alternative. Emerging from earlier political efforts of farmers, such as the Granger movement and the Farmer’s Alliance, the Populists attracted not only rural white male farmers, but also African American farmers and women reformers. This primary source set highlights prominent Populists, propaganda from political campaigns, and political arguments of the movement. After reading and viewing these documents, assess how central the “common people” are to the movement.
